10.text:
Hello and welcome to this talk about alternative
sources of postgraduate funding. So this talk

14.text:
is really I suppose about the kind of unusual
postgraduate funding sources that you may

19.text:
not have heard very much about, principally
charities, trusts and foundations. There are

24.text:
many thousands of alternative funding bodies
that exist out there in Britain which will

29.text:
potentially fund postgraduate study and indeed
potentially fund more or less anybody actually

34.text:
in some cases who make a strong case for funding,
whether they're a student or not. So this

39.text:
is very much I guess the thing to consider,
you know, if you are not successful with I

43.text:
guess one of the more conventional mainstream
sources of funding such as Research Councils

48.text:
or university scholarships. To introduce myself,
I funded my entire PhD in fact in Political

56.text:
History at Kings College London through using
these charities and trusts, winning about

61.text:
forty different awards. I say those numbers
not to blow my own trumpet but to, I suppose,

67.text:
convince you that some of what I'm going to
talk about in the next few minutes is actually

70.text:
real because some of the funding does seem
a little bit bizarre on the face of it.

75.text:
OK, so I guess the first question would be
who is this talk actually aimed at? Well I

81.text:
would have said that it's really all postgraduate
students. Whether you are interested in doing

85.text:
a Masters or you're interested in doing a
PhD, charities and trusts will potentially

90.text:
be eligible to help you out. In fact, actually
charities and trusts in many ways don't mind

96.text:
whether they're funding a Masters student,
a PhD student or indeed even an undergraduate

101.text:
student, or indeed even a current or a prospective
student. You can apply in advance of your

106.text:
course starting or indeed during your course
as well. Also charities and trusts can be

113.text:
used by students who are partially funded.
So, for example, you might have a partial

118.text:
scholarship from some particular source, or
if you are entirely self-funded. In additional

124.text:
also a fourth year PhD student can use these
charities as well, for example maybe you get

130.text:
a funded a PhD for three years and then you
have to fund the fourth year yourself. There

134.text:
are a lot of charities and trusts, for example
the Gilchrist Charitable Trust, the Yorkshire

139.text:
Ladies Council of Education and the Humanitarian
Trust, which are specifically for fourth year

145.text:
PhD students. You can also use charities to
fund research, travel and conference expenses;

151.text:
those kind of extra costs that you might incur
during your Masters and PhD. They might be

155.text:
a few thousand pounds maybe per year, they
might be more than that and there are some

159.text:
charities and trusts which exist explicitly
to fund those additional kind of courses rather

165.text:
than say fees and maintenance which I suppose
are your core course costs.

171.text:
So learning how to win these grants from charities
can be a really useful back-up option for

176.text:
you. Now what I'm going to go through in this
very very brief talk, which is only ever going

182.text:
to be a whistle-stop tour, is I'm going to
say a little bit more introducing these alternative

185.text:
funding bodies, I'm then going to tell you
how to find them and I'm then going to show

190.text:
you how to initially approach them with an
email or letter to make sure that you are

194.text:
eligible to apply to them and then how to
apply to them and some tips I guess for applying

200.text:
in the strongest fashion. I should say that
this whole talk is based upon a book called

206.text:
'The Alternative Guide to Postgraduate Funding',
which was the picture of the book that you

210.text:
saw in the introduction slide. Now, you can
get hold of a free CD version of 'The Alternative

216.text:
Guide to Postgraduate Funding', if you haven't
already got one today, from the reception

220.text:
at the Aston Webb Building -- that's the main
building where there will be a pile of these

223.text:
CDs here and that will have a pdf version
of 'The Alternative Guide to Postgraduate

228.text:
Funding, 2013-2014' there. So by all means,
you know, go and scoop up a copy of this book

234.text:
and take advantage of the fact that the university
is effectively offering it for free. That

240.text:
book has everything that I'm talking about
in this talk and also quite a bit more that

247.text:
Now when I talk about alternative funding
sources, I'm principally talking about charities,

252.text:
foundations and trusts. These words are pretty
much interchangeable I suppose as far as we're

255.text:
concerned and what they are, are simply bodies
which were set up and sustained by private

260.text:
individuals for all manner of reasons. You
might have some for example which are there

266.text:
to promote educational courses like the Sir
Richard Stapley Educational Trust or the St

270.text:
Clement Danes Educational Foundation. You
may have some actually that are restricted

274.text:
to specific student groups. So, for example,
some charities actually care about, for example,

280.text:
what your parents or even your grandparents,
actually did for a living. So for example

284.text:
there's one charity called the Leverhulme
Trades Charities Trust which will give you

287.text:
up to £5,000 a year for postgraduate study
if you are the son or daughter or grandson

293.text:
or granddaughter of a grocer, a travelling
salesman or a pharmacist. With that particular

299.text:
trust I actually got some funding from that
because my father used to sell biscuits in

302.text:
Grimsby in the 1970s. So that's an example
of the kind of level of obscurity you can

310.text:
sometimes run into. The Vegetarian Charity
for example only funds vegetarian and vegan

315.text:
students. Again, really really surprising,
why would somebody back something of that

321.text:
kind? There's a pub in Kent which has a charity
associated with it which gives out for all

326.text:
of the students who live within a 7.1 mile
radius of the second bar on the ground floor.

331.text:
That's another very very weird one. And the
weirdest one of all which is completely mad

335.text:
is called the Royal Golf Charitable Trust
which is run by a man on a golf course in

338.text:
Scotland and you can go to the golf course
and if you defeat him at a round of golf he

342.text:
gives you £5,000. [laughing] This is true.
I know it sounds like something in a video

346.text:
game. He's never been defeated because he's
really awesome. That said, they're not all

350.text:
mad, I just told you some of the mad ones
to entertain you before lunch. A lot of them

354.text:
are a lot more standardised like the Stapley
Trust, the Sidney Perry Foundation, Roger

358.text:
and Sarah Bancroft Clark Charitable Trust
which will more or less consider any postgraduate

363.text:
applicant. There you go, there's the Stapley
Trust that I mentioned, the Vegetarian Charity

367.text: and the Leverhulme Trades Charities Trust.

371.text:
So I guess the question is, you know, why
would you want to apply to this kind of alternative

374.text:
funding? Well, this is definitely a Plan B,
no question about that. If you can land, say,

379.text:
a full studentship which will pay all of our
fees, all of your maintenance, that is clearly

383.text:
the best thing for you to get. This kind of
funding is not as comprehensive as that. We're

388.text:
probably talking about much smaller awards
from here. Also you might use this kind of

395.text:
funding because your research costs, for example
travel and conferences, you may not know what

400.text:
they are and you may run into additional costs.
Also again maintenance things like independent

406.text:
living, obviously rent, food, that kind of
thing, again not necessarily possible to predict,

413.text:
especially when you are a prospective student
and haven't arrived at a university yet. And

416.text:
then of course there's the great unquantifiable
write-up costs. Will you finish a PhD in three

421.text:
years or will it probably go into a fourth
year like many PhDs do?

426.text:
I would have said that in the voluntary sector
they really are not at all like Research Councils

432.text:
and other kind of formal funding that you
will have probably come across before. Obviously

438.text:
Research Councils, things like the AHRC or
the ESRC which you probably have already heard

442.text:
about today at the earlier postgraduate funding
talk, have very very strict requirements.

447.text:
You have to apply a long time in advance and
they're very academic in their nature. But

454.text:
these charities and trusts though, there are
thousands of bodies, from really big ones

457.text:
-- for example like Oxfam to the British Heart
Foundation to the Welcome Trust -- down to

462.text:
really really small ones which are probably
just run by a few volunteers at weekends from

466.text:
a farmhouse for example and these small bodies,
there are many many more of the small bodies,

471.text:
are probably the ones that you will be looking
at when you come to look at this for postgraduate

478.text:
Now what about how much you can get? Well
obviously these charities have got varying

481.text:
budgets. Probably per award we're talking
about something like £500 to £2,000. Some

487.text:
of them are bigger, for example the Leverhulme
Trades Charities Trust, but the really really

491.text:
good thing about these charities and trusts
is that you can win multiple awards. You can

495.text:
build up a basketful of them. Once you've
won one it's actually easier to win two, to

499.text:
win three, to win many and so there's a snowball
effect. Also you can win them for each year

505.text:
of your PhD for example. I guess part-time
Masters, you know, a two year Masters course.

511.text:
So that £1,000 in year one might be £2,000
in year two, £3,000 in year three, £4,000

517.text:
in year four etc. They're also not always
academic. Some of them just help members of

521.text:
the general public. You might be competing
against a charity which helps a residents'

526.text:
association fix some swings or someone doing
an NVQ in brick laying and obviously your

533.text:
application to do a PhD or Masters at Birmingham
might go alongside that. I mentioned that

538.text:
they've got pretty weird eligibility criteria
some of them and they really vary.

542.text:
There's also of course another area which
are professional bodies and learned societies,

546.text:
things like the Royal Historical Society and
the Society for Neuroscience, which can help

552.text:
with conference costs and so on and so forth.
But they are very diverse and hopefully there

556.text:
will be something for everyone here. Also
charities are flexible. They usually have

560.text:
many deadlines per year -- sometimes four,
sometimes six, sometimes twelve -- where the

564.text:
trustees meet. And you can also, as I said
before, apply in advance or during your course.

570.text:
Now what about finding charities and trusts?
Well, there are a variety of ways that you

573.text:
can go about that but the main methodology
I think is to try and spread the net as far

579.text:
as you can, try and get like a pad of paper
and try and find as many charities that you

585.text:
think you will be eligible for at first instance,
because the amount of information that there

589.text:
is available on charities via books and via
the internet, is not always complete. You

594.text:
may actually find that many charities which
look perfect for you, you're not actually

597.text:
eligible for. So what you need to do at first
is to make, say, a long list of charities

602.text:
you think you're eligible for and then send
them a letter or email to make sure, and I'll

606.text:
come to that in a minute. Don't discount a
charity that you find however in a book or

611.text:
the internet unless it's obviously inappropriate
because many are quite flexible. But the one

616.text:
thing you should be wary of when you look
for charities is make sure they make awards

619.text:
to individuals. Most charities do not. Most
charities only make awards to organisations

625.text:
and you will almost certainly be applying
as an individual.

629.text:
So where can you look for charities? Well
the first place is online using a variety

634.text:
of internet sites. Obviously look at Birmingham's
funding pages, you've probably already thought

639.text:
of that. Also look at the charities list in
the 'The Alternative Guide to Postgraduate

643.text:
Funding', that publication I mentioned. That
has a list in the purple pages at the back

648.text:
of over 400 charities and trusts which have
been sourced by me and my team which make

652.text:
awards to postgraduate study. That might be
an absolutely ideal place to start and if

656.text:
you're not looking to raise such a large amount
of money, you might get everything you need

660.text:
conceivably just through that list. You can
also look on a variety of other websites.

665.text:
The URLs for these are all in the Alternative
Guide by the way. Postgraduate studentships,

669.text:
the general funders' section, not the main
section. Scholarship search, although that's

674.text:
not that useful. RD funding, Research and
Development funding, especially the long-shot

678.text:
section, Unigrants which is really really
good for charities that are specific to subjects,

683.text:
and charities that are specific to postcodes.
Research professional, which is a resource

687.text:
that the university here at Birmingham subscribes
to, that's great for research, travel and

691.text:
conference costs and also the British Council
maybe, especially if you are an international

696.text:
student. You can also look at charity search
engines as well. These are search engines

701.text:
set up for members of the public, not necessarily
students. By far the best one in this category

705.text:
is called Turn To Us. You can also look in
your local library as well. There are a variety

712.text:
of really interesting books that you will
be able to find there. So they're the titles

717.text:
of those. Also you have the Charities Digest
as well and there are a variety of other books

721.text:
that you might well find in your local library
when you come to look for this. Just have

725.text:
a look and ask the librarian to show you where
they are and they'll all be there. I think

730.text:
it's actually a legal requirement for most
public libraries to hold copies of these books.

737.text:
There are also local books on charities as
well that you might find, like if you go and

741.text:
look in, I don't know, Birmingham Selly Oak
or something like that, you know, you might

745.text:
find some local books that relate to that.
There's also the learned societies I mentioned,

752.text:
things like the Society for Neuroscience,
Royal Historical Society, Royal Society of

756.text:
British Artists, London Mathematical Society.
You're probably familiar with some of those.

762.text:
They're interested generally in promoting
a specific area of research and they're great

765.text:
for conferences and research costs. You can
find those actually just by Googling the name

770.text:
of your subject with Royal Society and you
might get a few leads like that.

775.text:
But hopefully having looked on the internet
and looked in the library you will have then

780.text:
built up quite a large number of charities
you think you're eligible for, but you can

784.text:
still get quite a few more by asking for advice.
You can ask some people called the Educational

788.text:
Grants Advisory Service, or EGAS. The URL
is again in the Alternative Guide, you can

792.text:
just Google EGAS and you can write to them
with some biographical details about yourself

798.text:
and they can send you a list of potential
funders that they think you're eligible for,

803.text:
which is fairly useful. Also you can have
a look at the educational division of your

807.text:
local council as well. Sometimes local councils
act as the trustees to charities which, I

814.text:
suppose, have fallen into disrepair. Maybe
their trustees have died or they've moved

817.text:
onto something else and the grant-making powers
are absorbed by the local charity. You could

822.text:
also even write to the clerk of your local
parish council. Parish councils are the smallest

827.text:
units of local Government in England, they
exist in about a third of postcodes in England

830.text:
and Wales. Sometimes, rarely, they have money
they might be prepared to give away and the

834.text:
way you found out about those guys is ask
your local council, ask the general enquiries

840.text:
team, tell them what your postcode is and
ask them for contact details of your parish

844.text:
council, if you've got a parish council. So
that's another line of enquiry and then obviously

849.text:
of course, you know, just simply ask at your
department as well. There are many, many ways

854.text: of finding out about these things.

856.text:
So, you've got this big list now, what are
you going to do with it? Well, you've got

860.text:
to try and make sure that you are actually
eligible for these charities before you apply

864.text:
to them. So what you've got to do is you've
got to write an initial letter or email of

868.text:
enquiry, or give them a phone call of course
if they have a number. This letter should

872.text:
be very simple. Just state your name, your
course and that you're looking to overcome

875.text:
a deficit in your funding package in this
particular programme. An example of what an

879.text:
initial letter of enquiry looks like can be
found on page 72, I believe, of the Alternative

884.text:
Guide to Postgraduate Funding, but it should
be very short and is not the place to advance

889.text:
complicated arguments about your research.
It's really just simply to give them enough

895.text:
information to decide whether you are eligible
or not. Make it polite, short and certain-sounding

902.text:
and also be prepared to send out quite a lot
of letters. In my case I probably sent out

907.text:
over a hundred. You don't necessarily need
to go that far but the more you send out,

912.text: the more potential leads you will get.

916.text:
When you send out letters in the post though,
always be careful to include a stamped self-addressed

921.text:
envelope. That's just an envelope with your
address on it and sufficient postage to pay

925.text:
for maybe six or eight sheets of paper that
are folded. Probably an A5 envelope is ideal.

931.text:
Obviously if they have an email address you
can use that but many charities, shall we

934.text:
say, exist or are run by people from the pre-internet
generation, shall we say, and so consequently

940.text:
often do not have websites or email addresses.
But what I would say is send out all of those

947.text:
things -- emails, letters and stuff -- then
await results. Lots of charities will not

951.text:
reply to you. Probably 40%, 50% won't. Of
those who do reply to you, lots of them will

957.text:
go and whip out some eligibility criteria
that you weren't aware of and you won't be

961.text:
eligible. Some of them will say they only
fund organisations and not individuals and

967.text:
then others may simply say that we don't have
any money at the moment and we're not giving

970.text:
any grants. But, from those that do actually
get back to you and invite you to apply, you

977.text:
have a pretty good chance in most cases of
actually getting an award from those bodies.

981.text:
With charities and trusts, the real challenge
is finding them and getting them to invite

985.text:
you to apply to them, not so much actually
applying to them, like it is with these other

990.text:
scholarships that you've heard about before
from Research Councils for example, which

994.text:
are very well known about but hugely competitive.
With charities it's the opposite. Charities

998.text: are not so competitive but are very very obscure.

1002.text:
Now hopefully when you get some application
forms you need to now decide what to do with

1006.text:
them. You need to decide how you're going
to fill them in to give yourself the best

1010.text:
chance of success. So fill in each section
very carefully, obviously, and decide what

1016.text:
a charity's priority is, whether it's your
research, whether it's the benefit to the

1020.text:
wider society which many charities are interested
in, or whether they're interested in, I guess,

1024.text:
in your kind of career progression. Or maybe
whether they're interested in simply helping

1029.text:
you because your father was a greengrocer
or something like that. Maybe tailor your

1033.text:
application to them with the odd couple of
lines but don't go overboard because you want

1037.text:
to be able to re-use your statement to a large
extent when you apply to other charities.

1043.text:
500 to 800 words, something like that for
a personal statement. Obviously make your

1047.text:
research, especially if you are doing a PhD,
easy to understand and try and show how it

1052.text:
can benefit society. Now I understand that
for someone like a Historian like me, that

1056.text:
is quite challenging relative to say a scientist
who can just say 'well, I'm saving lives,

1060.text:
man'. I can't say that but at least try and
make it interesting and understandable and

1065.text:
accessible, particularly if you are in the
arts and humanities. Charities are not run

1069.text:
by academics but well-informed members of
the general public, so don't go on about your

1073.text:
re-assessment of the post-Hegelian dialectic
because people won't understand what that

1077.text:
is. Try and put it in layman terms. Also list
other charities that you've applied for or

1083.text:
you've received money from. Charities like
the idea of being in partnership with other

1087.text:
funders, they don't like the idea of simply
being the sole provider of a particular student.

1093.text:
Try and also show a clear financial plan.
The charity needs to feel as though it is

1097.text:
part of something bigger, that you've thought
about how to fund your Masters or PhD, that

1101.text:
you haven't just opened a book, stuck a pin
in it and applied to that charity. Charities

1105.text:
will not respond well to that. Although they
are compassionate bodies they also have to

1108.text:
be run like businesses and they want to be
able to fund students who they are very confident

1113.text:
will finish their course because many students
of course do not finish postgraduate courses

1118.text:
that they start sometimes. Also have a clear
vocational aim. Some charities may think that

1123.text:
you're doing your course because it's an indulgence.
Show that you're not. Show that you're doing

1128.text: it to actually get a job.

1130.text:
Right, your financial statement. Now most
charities will ask you for one of these. What

1135.text:
this should really be is just actually a table
of income and expenses and a list of charities

1140.text:
that you are applying to in this academic
year or next academic year I guess, with the

1145.text:
results if known. And you need to itemise
your income and expenditure and you should

1150.text:
request an amount based on the deficit between
your income and expenditure. I will show you

1154.text: what this looks in a minute.

1157.text:
OK, so this is a typical kind of financial
statement. So you see there on the right there

1162.text:
are other charities that this person has applied
for in this particular year of academic study,

1166.text:
along with the amount of money and whether
the outcome is known or not. In this case

1170.text:
this person's got a six grand deficit and
so you should ask therefore the charity I

1176.text:
suppose for an amount based on that deficit.
If the charity will give you guidance on the

1180.text:
maximum amount of award you can apply for,
say £2,000, you will probably want to maybe

1186.text:
ask for a little bit less than all of that
to avoid sounding greedy, but obviously if

1190.text:
your deficit is bigger than the maximum award
that a charity makes, you need to show the

1194.text:
charity that you've thought about how to get
the rest of it, maybe through listing bodies

1197.text:
on that sheet. You will also need references
as well, maybe from your supervisor or potential

1204.text:
supervisor, maybe someone else, maybe at the
university where you did your undergraduate

1208.text:
-- anyone you can think of who's sympathetic
to your work and is from an established university.

1213.text:
References are there to make sure you are
who you say you are in the case of charities.

1216.text:
It doesn't really matter whether you've got
a Nobel prize winning professor writing your

1220.text:
reference with charities. Charities get a
lot of scammers, as you might imagine, and

1224.text:
they just want to make sure that you are the
real deal and obviously a lecturer as reference

1227.text:
from a university will help them do that.
Be neat and diligent with the forms obviously

1232.text:
and if you're successful, just write to say
thanks and with a short half-page report at

1235.text:
the end of the year. That's not just courteous
but it ensures you'll probably get the money

1239.text:
next year if you re-apply again. And indeed
of course you can renew those awards.

1244.text:
Right, I've nearly finished but just some
brief golden rules through this very very

1250.text:
dense and very whistle-stop tour of the world
of alternative funding sources. Golden rule

1254.text:
number one, make sure you're eligible. Make
sure that you are eligible for this charity

1260.text:
by sending that initial letter or email of
enquiry. Don't just send an application having

1264.text:
just looked at the website because you'll
probably just get rejected because you've

1268.text:
missed something. Second, understand the charity's
priority and tailor your application just

1272.text:
a little bit but don't go overboard because
you might want to re-use substantial parts

1276.text:
of your application when you apply to others.
If you're doing a research course, keep it

1283.text:
simple, make it layman terms and try and show
how it benefits society as well. Also show

1291.text:
that vocational purpose, make sure that your
course doesn't sound like an indulgence because

1295.text:
many people, ignorantly of course, believe
that postgraduate study is an indulgence in

1300.text:
wider society. Be sure to show them that it
jolly well isn't. And also have that clear

1304.text:
financial plan to make the charity feel as
though it is part of a broader funding picture

1309.text:
and that you are a well-organised student
and the charity is not simply the recipient

1314.text: of an ad-hoc plea for help.

1317.text:
Never give up. Well, I suppose I would never
say never but at the same time, every application

1323.text:
you make, every initial letter of enquiry
you send off, is effectively a gamble with

1327.text:
your time, a throw of the metaphorical dice,
a spin of the proverbial wheel and the more

1334.text:
times you ultimately do these things, the
more chances you have of eventually succeeding.

1339.text:
I apologise if I was a bit like a machine
gun there but there was a lot to get through

1344.text:
and the guide will have it all in more detail
for you to consider at your leisure. Thank
